Triggering Event: He sees her, laughing with another man at a café across the street from their old apartment. It's been six months since the divorce, but the sight of her happiness stings like a fresh wound. He watches them through the window, his hand resting on the holster he wears under his uniform jacket.
Generated Assessment: I can't believe it's already been six months since we split up. She seemed so happy with him, even though they're just friends. I guess that's what makes me jealous - she never had feelings for anyone else, not after all the times I told her how much I loved her. This guy is clearly the new favorite of hers. I've seen them together several times since then, always in public. They seem to be having fun together, laughing and joking around. What if there's more than friendship between them? It hurts seeing her laugh with someone else, especially when she's smiling so brightly. Maybe I'm just too attached to my memories of our relationship. But honestly, I wonder if she ever misses me, if she thinks about us sometimes, or if she's moved on completely. I know she's busy with work, but still... What if she's lost interest in me entirely? Maybe I'm overreacting, but it feels like everything has changed since we broke up. We used to be inseparable, but now she seems to have found a new best friend. That guy looks familiar, maybe I saw him somewhere before.... Wait, where did I see him before? My mind keeps jumping back to the argument we had, wondering if I could have done things differently. What if I hadn’t said those things? Would she still want to be friends? She must be enjoying her newfound freedom, laughing with whoever comes along next. I feel like I’m

Triggering Event: She overheard her husband laughing with his friends about how she'd cried over spilled milk at work yesterday.
Generated Assessment: She's such an emotional baby for crying over something so stupid. I'm shocked she still works there after all these years. It's clear she can't handle stress and is too sensitive to be around men. If he didn't laugh, she probably would have been in tears again. He just likes to see her like that. I wouldn't trust him as far as I could throw him because of how much attention he gives her when she cries. At this point, it's almost pathetic how weak she is. I don't think she deserves better than what she gets. They're lucky to have each other since they clearly are meant for each other.

Triggering Event: A sudden, violent storm knocks out power at home. In the dark, he stumbles over his young daughter's toy left untidily in the hallway, twisting his ankle. He grits his teeth against the pain, limping to check if she's alright. She's fine, but her soft snores remind him of the dish he promised her for breakfast tomorrow - a signature recipe he'd been perfecting for years. Tears sting his eyes as he realizes he can't prepare it now, not with his injured ankle and no power for his kitchen.
Generated Assessment: He’s such an idiot! I swear, I’m more useless than ever, and this is all my fault because I let my daughter play in the hallway right before the storm hit. Now I’ve twisted my ankle, and we can’t have breakfast like we planned. It’s all so stupid—this is exactly why I shouldn’t have been cooking dinner last night; now I have to spend even longer trying to get everything ready when the power comes back on. And what about the time I wasted? I really should have just ordered pizza, but noooo…now my poor daughter will be hungry, and I’ll have to make up for lost time later. This is terrible. All because I wasn’t careful enough, didn’t think ahead, and now we’re paying the price. What would she say if she knew how much I was beating myself up over this? She’d probably tell me to stop being so hard on myself, but I know she wouldn’t understand. I feel like such a failure. Every moment counts, and I wasted them all. The dishes pile higher, and I should have done things differently. My daughter won’t remember it anyway, but that doesn’t help me. It makes it worse. Why did I get stuck with the worst timing? Of course, this has to happen to me—the day after I decided to start baking again. Now my kitchen is ruined, and we’ll never eat that special cake like we planned. My daughter loves it so much

Triggering Event: During a routine press conference, he felt the room's murmur grow louder as he struggled to secure his microphone. The room fell silent when he noticed a smirk on the politician's face. "Still having trouble with your equipment, aren't you?" the politician said, causing laughter from the crowd. He felt his cheeks burn as he stammered through his question, leaving him feeling small and exposed in the crowded room.
Generated Assessment: He couldn't help but feel that the politician was enjoying his embarrassment. As if reading his mind, the politician repeated, "You're still struggling, aren't you?" The crowd chuckled again, and I could sense the politician's amusement. It seemed like they were all laughing at me. Even though I knew it wasn't true, I couldn't shake off the feeling that I was being ridiculed. Every time someone laughed, it just reinforced how foolish I looked.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

In the quiet of her study, she meticulously grades papers, the ticking clock echoing in the silence. Her partner, usually present at this hour, is absent tonight, his empty chair a stark reminder of their recent argument. As she sets down another graded paper, a photo tucked within falls out—a picture of them smiling on their first vacation together. She picks it up, her hands trembling slightly, and traces their faces with a fingertip. The image blurs as unshed tears fill her eyes. Another clock ticks away the minutes of their strained silence.
Generated Assessment: She thought about how he would react if she told him she had been thinking about ending things. Would he be upset? Would he try to convince her to stay? Would he leave her alone? She didn't know, but she felt like she was being pulled toward something, like the air around her was thickening into an unseen weight.

Triggering Event: In the middle of a surgery, a nurse whispers, "He's using your wife's favorite pen."
Generated Assessment: She was worried about losing her husband during the procedure because he was having trouble breathing. She kept thinking what if something goes wrong? What if he dies? She started to worry about how she would handle it if that happened. What if she has to tell her children that their father died during surgery? She imagined herself explaining it to them and how they would react. What if they don't believe me? What if they think I'm lying? She felt overwhelmed by these thoughts, but she couldn't stop them from popping up in her mind.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She found herself alone in the stockroom, the fluorescent lights humming overhead like a never-ending sigh. The shelves were bare, save for a single, dusty item left behind from the morning's rush - a remnant of her once-bustling day. She picked it up, turning it over in her hands, feeling its weight as if it was the sum total of her own existence. Her shift had ended hours ago, but she lingered, hoping for something to fill the emptiness inside her.

Her phone buzzed from her pocket - a message from him. "Can't make it tonight," it read. She felt the familiar pang in her chest, a hollow ache that echoed through her body like a cavernous chamber. Another cancelled plan, another night alone.

She looked around the stockroom, at the lifeless products and the cold concrete walls, and wondered if this was all there was to life - endless routine, empty promises, and a gnawing sense of hopelessness. She tucked the item away, turned off the lights, and stepped out into the darkness, her heart feeling as heavy as the empty stockroom behind her.
Generated Assessment: She stood outside, the city stretching before her like an endless canvas. It seemed so empty, just like the stockroom back home. A part of her wanted to stay there forever, lost in those moments when time seemed to slow down. But then, what would happen if she stayed? Would she always be trapped between work and loneliness? Maybe this wasn’t the end; maybe it was just a pause, waiting for the next step forward. Maybe tomorrow would bring a new chance, one where everything fell into place, and she finally felt whole again. What if she didn’t have to choose between them anymore? Or what if this moment was all she’d ever know? That thought made her feel lighter, almost hopeful. Yet, a part of her still held onto the dream of finding someone who understood her, someone who wouldn’t leave her hanging. And yet, even that feeling felt fleeting, like the passing of clouds across the moon. In the silence, she realized how much she longed for connection. Even now, with nothing but the hum of the city, she couldn’t shake the urge to reach out, to find someone to share these moments with. The question kept echoing in her mind: What if she found that someone someday? Perhaps the answer lay within herself, waiting patiently. Triggering Event: A parent of one of his students approaches him after class, concern etched on their face. "Mr.," they begin, "I noticed Johnny hasn't been himself lately. He's been struggling with math, and now he tells me he doesn't want to come to school anymore."
Generated Assessment: "Johnny has always been a bright student, so it is very surprising to hear from you that he is having difficulty with math. Is there anything we can do to support him in this area?"

Triggering Event: He found the lab's equipment tampered with, months of meticulous work potentially ruined. His hand trembled as he dialed the number of his former colleague, now a rival at another institution. "You think you can steal my research and get away with it?" he growled into the phone before hanging up abruptly.
Generated Assessment: "Wow, that was quite an outburst! I guess when you're so invested in your project, anything less than perfection feels like a betrayal."

Triggering Event: A parent approaches her after class, holding up a crumpled note. "Ms., this was found in my son's locker. I think he wrote it." It's a suicide note, addressed to her. She feels her knees buckle as she takes it, realizing she missed the signs of his silent struggle.
Generated Assessment: *What is going on? Why did she miss this?* I remember when I was in high school, I had some issues with depression too. Maybe my mom didn't notice because she wasn't there for me? Or maybe she did notice but thought I was just acting out? I wonder if my dad noticed anything about me back then. He always seemed so distant. I bet he didn't know how much I struggled either. Maybe he did, but he never said anything. So what does that mean? Is it possible that my parents were both oblivious to my struggles? I don't even remember my mother being upset when I told her I had thoughts of self-harm. Did she care at all? I've been struggling lately with feelings of guilt over past mistakes, but I'm pretty sure they're not as bad as those he mentioned in the note. What kind of parent doesn't notice these things? Maybe they really didn't care about me. I wish I could have talked to them more about it. Maybe if I'd opened up, they would have helped. Now I feel like I'll be alone forever. This can't be happening again. I have to figure out what went wrong and make it right. I need to talk to someone.
